dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although we do not see the foreground window frame, we se the whole background of a Greenwich Village street. We can see the rear of a number of assorted houses and sm apartment buildings whose fronts face on the next cross-t street, sharply etched by the morning sun. Some are two stories high; others three; some have peaked roofs, others are flat. There is a mixture of brick and w and wrought iron in the construction. The apartment buildings have fire escapes, the others do  not. The neighborhood is not a prosperous one, but neither is poor. It is a practical, conventional dwelling place for  people living on marginal incomes, luck -- or hope and ca planning. The summer air is motionless and heavy with humid heat. It has opened windows wide, pushed back curtains, lifted  blinds and generally brought the neighborhood life into a sweltering intimacy. Yet, people born and bred to life wi earshot and eye glance of a score of neighbors have learn to preserve their own private worlds by uniformly ignorin each other, except on direct invitation. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK until a large sleeping profile of a man fills the screen. It is so large that we do not see a features, but merely the temple and side of the cheek dow which a stream of sweat is running. THE CAMERA PANS OFF this to the right hand side of the wi and MOVES TO a thermometer which is hanging on the wall j outside the window. It registers 84. THE CAMERA MOVES ON into the open, and brings nearer to u room with a large studio window. We are able to see insid this room. A short, balding man is standing near the wind shaving, using a small bowl of water and a portable mirro which he has set up on a shelf. To the right of him is a battered upright piano. On top o the piano is a radio. The music selection coming from the radio stops, and the announcer is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The time -- 7:15 A.M., WOR, New York.  The temperature, outside, 84 --  Friends -- is your life worth one  dollar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man shaving quickly puts down his razor, hurries to t radio, and changes the station, moving past a number of  commercial voices until he again finds some music. Contented, he returns to his shaving. THE CAMERA MOVES ON AND OVER to a far building. It passes over the face of this building until it comes to fire esc It goes up and near enough to one which has become the ou bedroom of a couple. We are near enough to see an alarm c hanging from the rail which is now ringing vigorously. A rises lazily to a sitting position. He gropes to switch t alarm off. We see that his pajamas are stained with sweat. In his si position he leans forward and shakes somebody beside him. our surprise, the head of this other person -- a woman -- rises where his feet are. They have been sleeping in oppo directions. They sit limply looking at each other with  bedraggled and weary expressions which show they enjoyed  very little sleep in the heat of the night. THE CAMERA NOW MOVES DOWN toward the left onto another lo building. It MOVES IN A LITTLE to a living room window. J inside the windowsill, a small fan is oscillating. The fa sits on the right side of the table, and to the left of i is an automatic toaster. Behind the toaster stands a full-bodied young woman,  apparently wearing only a pair of black panties. Her stom navel, and the lower part of her chest are naked. Just be her breasts, the curtain, partly drawn, has thrown a deep shadow which extends upward, hiding her breasts, shoulder and head. Two pieces of toast pop up in the toaster. She  takes them out, butters them. Then she turns around and b over another table on which stands an automatic coffee-ma She picks up the coffee-maker, and swings back to the tab to sit down. She does this so deftly that her breasts are never exposed, but hidden by the fan as she sits down. Th fan moves back and forth as she pours coffee, far enough reveal that she wears no bra, but not far enough to fulfi the exciting promise of her lack of clothes. THE CAMERA MOVES ON to a distant street corner seen betwe two buildings. The traffic is very light at this hour, bu Sanitation Department truck moves through the intersectio spraying water out behind it to cool the pavement and kee the dust down. Three little kids in bathing suits run beh the truck, playing in the water. THE CAMERA MOVES OFF and around to some buildings at the  side. As it skims this building, we see a hand emerge fro one of the windows, and remove the cover from a birdcage  which is hanging from a hook on the wall outside. In the  cage are two lovebirds -- arguing. THE CAMERA NOW PULLS BACK SWIFTLY and retreats through th open window back into Jefferies' apartment. We now see mo of the sleeping man. THE CAMERA GOES IN far enough to sho head and shoulders of him. He is L. B. JEFFERIES. A tall, lean, energetic thirty fiv his face long and serious-looking at rest, is in other  circumstances capable of humor, passion, naive wonder and the kind of intensity that bespeaks inner convictions of  moral strength and basic honesty. He is sitting in an Everest and Jennings wheelchair. THE CAMERA PANS along his right leg. It is encased in a  plaster of Paris spica from his waistline to the base of toes. Along the white cast someone has written "Here lie broken bones of L. B. Jefferies." THE CAMERA PANS to a nearby table on which rests a shatte and twisted Speed Graphic Camera, the kind used by fast-a news photographers. On the same table, the CAMERA PANS to an eight by ten glo photo print. It shows a dirt track auto racing speedway,  taken from a point dangerously near the center of the tra A racing car is skidding toward the camera, out of contro spewing a cloud of dust behind it. A rear wheel has come the car, and the wheel is bounding at top speed directly  into the camera lens. THE CAMERA MOVES UP to a framed photograph on the wall. It is a fourteen by ten print, an essay in violence, havi caught on film the exploding semi-second when a heavy  artillery shell arches into a front-line Korean battle  outpost. Men and equipment erupt into the air suspended i solution of blasted rock, dust and screeching shrapnel. T the photographer was not a casualty is evident, but surpr when the short distance between the camera and the explos is estimated. A signature in the lower right hand corner the picture reads -- "L. B. Jefferies." THE CAMERA PANS to a second photograph of a picket line a an aircraft plant strike. Strikers, non-strikers and poli are embroiled in a bitter and confused riot. Clubs, fists and truncheons swing, blood flows, faces twi with emotion and fallen victims struggle to regain their  feet. The picture represents no distant, cautions photogr observation, but rather an intimate report, so immediate real that the viewer has the nervous feeling the fight  surrounds him and he had best defend himself. The same  signature, "L. B. Jefferies," is in the corner. THE CAMERA PANS TO another framed picture, this one a  beautiful and awesome shot of an atomic explosion at  Frenchman's Flat, Nevada. It is the cul-de-sac of violenc The picture taken at a distant observation point, shows s spectators in the foreground watching the explosion throu binoculars. THE CAMERA MOVES ON to a shelf containing a number of cam photographic film, etc. It then PAN ACROSS a large viewer which is resting a negative of a woman's head. From this, THE CAMERA MOVES ON to a magazine cover, and  although we do not see the name of the magazine, we can s the head on the cover is the positive of the negative we  have just passed. THE CAMERA FINALLY COMES TO REST ON a pile of magazines - perhaps a hundred or so. They are all of the same publica

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen is filled with the top of a desk. In addition the usual telephones, blotting pad, etc., the most promin feature is the number of glossy photo prints, and even la sized mat prints. Some of them have slips pasted over wit descriptions. The center of the desk is occupied by a lar layout of photographs on one magazine page. Behind this w hear the murmur of two voices of men who can be vaguely s beyond the desk. THE CAMERA PANS UP and we are now face to face with IVAR  GUNNISON and JACK BRYCE. Gunnison is sitting on a window- ledge, and beyond him we realize we are high above the Ne York streets. Bryce leans against a wall at right angles him. Gunnison is holding a cablegram in his hand. Bryce has a  cigarette in his mouth. He scratches a match, and is abou to light it, when he notices that Gunnison, still reading the cable, has reached into an inside shirt pocket, and  produced a cigarette. Quickly, Bryce moves over to light  Gunnison's cigarette. Then he settles back to light his o Gunnison doesn't even bother to thank him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks up) Indo-China -- Jeff predicted it would  go sky-high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the looks of Davidson's cable,  it might even go higher than that.  And we haven't even got a camera  over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stands) This could go off in a month -- or  an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pull somebody out of Japan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Heads for his phone) Bryce, the only man for this job is  sitting right here in town. (Picks up phone) Get me L. B. Jefferies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Puzzled) Jefferies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Bryce; still  holding phone) Name me a better photographer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He can't) But his leg!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry -- it comes off today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce gives Gunnison a startled look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the cast. (To phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting through the open window, onto Jeff. He is shavin himself with an electric razor as the phone rings. He shu off the shaver, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On filter) Congratulations, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For getting rid of that cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said I was getting rid of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment, his attention is drawn to something acros the way. He looks up, expectantly. There is almost a touc of eagerness in his expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Jeff is continuing his phone conversation, we see t object of his look. Two pretty girls have appeared on the distant roof. They are smiling and talking, although we c hear their dialogue. Each wears a terrycloth robe. With t backs to the CAMERA, they take off the robes, slipping th down over their shoulders slowly. Then, seductively, they turn -- revealing the full beauty of their tanned and bat suited bodies. It is almost as if they want to be noticed the center of neighborhood attention. They at least have of Jeff's attention. Then they spread the robes in front them, and lie down on the roof, and out of sight. Jeff se a little disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the whole of this previous action, the conversatio between Jeff and Gunnison has gone on as follows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With logical proof) This is Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunnison -- how did you get to be  such a big editor -- with such a  small memory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong week. Next Wednesday I emerge  from this plaster cocoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad, Jeff. Well, I guess  I can't be lucky every day. Forget I  called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I sure feel sorry for you,  Gunnison. Must be rough on you  thinking of me wearing this cast  another whole week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunnison is now seated at his desk, with the phone receiv to his ear. His assistant, Bryce, can be seen vaguely in background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one week is going to cost me my  best photographer -- and you a big  assignment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff asks, eagerly and alertly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Gunnison's reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no point in even talking  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's eyes become set upon something else in the neighbo he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's attention is now drawn to another feature of his  backyard entertainment. THE CAMERA IS NOW FOCUSED on the  window of the small building where we earlier saw the gir behind the oscillating fan. Loud ballet music is pouring  from her open window. The girl, now dressed in dark and  revealing leotard, and ballet slippers, has just turned a from a portable record player. She begins the first grace movement of a modern ballet interpretation. She gracefully moves across the room to the rhythm of the music and dance, toward the ice box. With her feet still  moving, she throws open the door, and then rhythmically m back to the center of the room, gnaws the chicken bone,  occasionally waving it in the air as part of the choreogr She now twirls over toward a table at the other side of t room on which is an open package of bread slices, some bu nearby. With swaying body, she puts down the chicken leg, and  gracefully and rhythmically butters a slice of bread. She picks up both bread and chicken leg and continues her interpretive dance, alternately munching the bread and bu and chicken leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's eyes drop from the ballet dancer's room to the one underneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PANS from the window of the dancing girl, to t window below. Someone is reading the New York Herald Trib The paper lowers, and we see an elderly lady, in her late sixties. She is a faded, refined type. She looks up in th direction of the music and in a calm routine fashion adju the volume of her hearing aid. She resumes her reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is amused by what he sees, but continues his convers with Gunnison, which has gone on through all the scenes w the ballet dancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Insistent) Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Filter) Indo-China. Got a code tip from the  bureau chief this morning. The place  is about to go up in smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pleased; excited) Didn't I tell you! Didn't I tell you  it was the next place to watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On filter) Okay. When do I leave? Half-hour? An  hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that cast on -- you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On filter) Stop sounding stuffy. I'll take  pictures from a jeep. From a water  buffalo if necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too valuable to the magazine  for us to play around with. I'll  send Morgan or Lambert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swell. I get myself half-killed for  you -- and you reward me by stealing  my assignments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you to stand in the  middle of that automobile race track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A little angry) You asked for something dramatically  different! You got it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) So did you. Goodbye, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Won't let him hang  up) You've got to get me out of here!  Six weeks -- sitting in a two-room  apartment with nothing to do but  look out the window at the neighbors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment we hear the sounds of a piano playing. It is a simple, but broken, melody as if someone was just learning to play the piano, or carefully composing a song It clashes abruptly with the music from the ballet dancer apartment. It irritates Jeff as he looks in the direction the new music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worse than the Chinese water  torture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now see the source of the piano music. It comes from t apartment with the studio window which we saw earlier whe the man was shaving and listening to the radio. The short balding man sits at the piano playing a few notes, then  transferring them by pencil to notepaper on the piano rac He continues this process, fighting the interference of t ballet music. The opening bars of his melody are beautifu and ear-catching. It is slow, hard work, and the ballet music finally becom such an interference that he gives up and walks to the wi to look down toward the dancer's apartment. He stands by a table at the window which is littered with records, the morning coffee cup, unwashed, the remains of breakfast, old newspapers, song sheets, etc. He takes a cigarette out of his mouth, looks for an ash t and ends up putting it out in the coffee cup. He then ret to the piano and begins picking out the melody the dancer playing on her record player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff frowns at the double sound, and raises his voice a  little. He continues the conversation which has been hear all through the previous scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read some good books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been taking pictures so long I  don't know how to read anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send you some comic books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Low, tense) Listen -- if you don't pull me out  of this swamp of boredom -- I'll do  something drastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On filter) I'll -- I'll get married. Then I'll  never be able to go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time you got married --  before you turn into a lonesome and  bitter old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you see me -- rushing home to a  hot apartment every night to listen  to the automatic laundry, the electric  dishwasher, the garbage disposal and  a nagging wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff -- wives don't nag anymore --  they discuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferies glances out across to the other apartments as h sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a three-storied, flat-roofed apartment house. The brick is weather-worn and faded. Each apartment has t windows facing the back, one showing a hallway, one a liv room, and the window on the right opening into a bedroom. On the second floor, a man has entered the living room fr a hallway door. He carries a large aluminum sample case c to salesmen. He sets down the case heavily, removes his h and slowly wipes his brow with the back of his right hand He takes off his coat and tie. His shirt is stained with  sweat underneath. He rolls up his sleeves, and his well- muscled arms heavy with hair confirm his dark, husky buil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his eyes still focused on the distant apartments, Je continues talking with Gunnison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Maybe in the high rent districts  they discuss -- but in my  neighborhood, they still nag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- you know best. Call you later,  Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time, have some good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up and resumes his attention on the apartment of the salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The salesman looks toward the bedroom door, hesitates, th reluctantly walks toward it. For a moment he is hidden by the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff shifts his look more to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man enters the bedroom. We can see a woman lying on t far bed. Near her, a small table is covered with medicine bottles, spoons, boxes of pills, a water pitcher and the  other impedimenta of the chronically ill. The woman sits as the man enters. She takes a wet cloth off her forehead Before the man even reaches her, she begins talking, some vigorously. Pointing to a wristwatch, she seems to be say something such as "You should have been home two hours ag I could be lying here dying for all you'd know -- or care The man stops short of the bed, makes gestures of trying placate her, but she goes on scolding. His attitude chang to weary patience, then irritation, then anger. He shouts back at her, turns and goes out of the room. Back in the living room, he picks up his hat, throws it  against the wall in anger, and leaves the apartment, slam the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's attention is suddenly diverted to himself. His leg under the cast, begins itching. He squirms, tries to move the leg a little. It gives no relief. He scratches the ou of the cast, but the itch gets worse. He reaches for a lo Chinese back scratcher lying on the windowsill. Carefully and with considerable ingenuity, he works it under the ca He scratches, and a look of sublime relief comes over his face. Satisfied, he takes the scratcher out. As he replac it on the windowsill, his attention is drawn back to the  scene outside the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the man who left his apartment in anger come out o the doorway into the backyard. He is easy to identify thr the color of his garish necktie. In one hand the man carr a small garden hoe and rake, and in the other a pair of  trimming shears. He goes to a small patch of flowers, per three feet square. They are beautiful, multi-colored three foot high zinnias He kneels down, inspects them, touches them affectionatel and with some pride. His anger seems to have left him,  replaced by the kind of peace that flowers bring many peo He stands up, carefully hoes the ground, them rakes it. T he snips a few leaves off the lower parts of the plant.  Finally, he waters them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's attention is turned to something else of interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the next door yard we see emerging from the apartmen below the ballet dancer, the elderly lady. She wear a broad sun hat, dark glasses, and a sunsuit  consisting of pink shorts and halter. She carries a copy the Herald Tribune, and still wears her hearing aid. She  settles into a folding, canvas deck chair. Her skin is dead white, and her body is thin to the point emaciation. No sooner has she settled into her chair, tha she is attracted by the sound of the salesman working in garden. She gets up, walks to the fence, and looks over. notices her, but doesn't speak. She begins gesturing to him how to take care of his flowe He listens for a moment, then looks directly at her. The  strong movements of his mouth show us that he objects  vigorously to the annoyance of her comments. She moves aw from the fence, started and a little shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is seated in the foreground, in a waist shot. Behind him, the entrance door to his apartment opens. STELLA McGAFFERY comes in. She is a husky, unhandsome, da haired woman who is dressed like a district nurse, with d coat, dark felt hat, with a white uniform showing underne the coat. She carries a small black bag. Stella pauses on the landing to watch Jeff. He doesn't ap to notice her entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Loud) The New York State sentence for a  peeping Tom is six months in the  workhouse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Stella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she comes down the stairs of the landing, holding on t wrought iron railing with one hand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there aren't any windows in the  workhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her bag down on a table. It is worn, and looks a if it belongs more to a fighter than a nurse. She takes o her hat coat, and hangs them on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Years ago, they used to put out your  eyes with a hot poker. Is one of  those bikini bombshells you always  watch worth a hot poker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't answer. She opens the bag, takes out some medi supplies: a thermometer, a stop watch, a bottle of rubbin oil, a can of powder, a towel. She talks as she works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've grown to be a race of peeping  Toms. What people should do is stand  outside their own houses and look in  once in a while. (She looks up at him) What do you think of that for homespun  philosophy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look at his face shows he doesn't think much of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Readers' Digest, April, 1939.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I only quote from the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the thermometer out of its case, shakes it down Looks at it. Satisfied, she walks to Jeff. She swings the wheelchair around abruptly to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff starts to protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, Stella --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoves the thermometer into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See it you can break a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she leaves him holding the thermometer THE CAMERA PULL BACK as she crosses to a divan. She takes a sheet from  underneath, and covers the divan with it. Talking, all th time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shoulda been a Gypsy fortune teller,  instead of an insurance company nurse.  I got a nose for trouble -- can smell  it ten miles away. (Stops, looks at him) You heard of the stock market crash  in '29?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff nods a bored "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I predicted it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Around thermometer) How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella stops for a moment, and looks at Jeff challengingl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple. I was nursing a director of  General Motors. Kidney ailment they  said. Nerves, I said. Then I asked  myself -- what's General Motors got  to be nervous about? (Snaps her fingers) Overproduction. Collapse, I answered.  When General Motors has to go to the  bathroom ten times a day -- the whole  country's ready to let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patient, suffering look comes over his face. He takes o the thermometer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella -- in economics, a kidney  ailment has no relationship to the  stock market. Absolutely none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It crashed, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff has no answer. Defeated, he puts the thermometer bac into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella goes on with her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can smell trouble right in this  apartment. You broke your leg. You  look out the window. You see things  you shouldn't. Trouble. I can see  you now, in front of the judge,  flanked by lawyers in blue double- breasted suits. You're pleading,  "Judge, it was only innocent fun. I  love my neighbors like a father." --  The Judge answers, "Congratulations.  You just gave birth to three years  in Dannemora."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PANS HER over to him. She takes out the  thermometer, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now I'd even welcome trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Flatly) You've got a hormone deficiency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell that from a  thermometer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those sultry sun-worshipers you watch  haven't raised your temperature one  degree in four weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets down the thermometer. Sterilizes it with a piece alcohol-soaked cotton in her other hand. She gets behind the wheelchair the CAMERA PULLS back as s pushes it over to the divan. She puts the thermometer awa in its case. Then she helps him off with his pajama top. helps him stand on one foot. He hops one step, then she lowers him, face down, on the  divan. She gets a bottle of rubbing oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is very low at one end of the divan. Jeff's he half-buried in the sheet, is large in the fore-ground. Beyond him Stella looms large and powerful-looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're right. There is going  to be some trouble around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella takes a handful of oil, slaps it on his back. He  winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you ever heat that stuff up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gives your circulation something to  fight. (Begins massaging his  back) What kind of trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa Fremont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be kidding. A beautiful  young woman, and you a reasonably  healthy specimen of manhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She expects me to marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slaps cold oils on  him) That's abnormal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Wincing) I'm not ready for marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. A man is always ready for  marriage -- with the right girl. And  Lisa Fremont is the right girl for  any man with half a brain, who can  get one eye open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Indifferent) She's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hits him with some more cold oil. He winces again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind every ridiculous statement is  always hidden the true cause. (Peers at him) What is it? You have a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After a pause) Her father loading up the shotgun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's happened before, you know! Some  of the world's happiest marriage  have started 'under the gun' you  might say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just not the girl for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's only perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too perfect. Too beautiful, too  talented, too sophisticated, too  everything -- but what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cautiously) Is what you want something you can  discuss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff gives an exasperated look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very simple. She belongs in  that rarefied atmosphere of Park  Avenue, expensive restaurants, and  literary cocktail parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People with sense can belong wherever  they're put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you see her tramping around the  world with a camera bum who never  has more than a week's salary in the  bank? (Almost to himself) If only she was ordinary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella sprinkles powder on his back, spreads it around. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK as she helps Jeff to a sitting posi He buttons on his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're never going to marry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably. But when I do, it'll be to  someone who thinks of life as more  than a new dress, a lobster dinner,  and the latest scandal. I need a  woman who'll go anywhere, do anything,  and love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA MOVES IN as she helps him into the wheelchair, listening to him with exaggerated attention. He, stops as notice her attitude. Then he goes on with less conviction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only honest thing to do is call  it off. Let her look for somebody  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can just hear you now. "Get out of  here you perfect, wonderful woman!  You're too good for me!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After pause) That's the hard part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She swings him around in front of the window. He starts t look out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Jefferies. I'm not educated.  I'm not even sophisticated. But I  can tell you this -- when a man and  a woman see each other, and like  each other -- they should come  together -- wham like two taxies on  Broadway. Not sit around studying  each other like specimens in at  bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an intelligent way to approach  marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Scoffing) Intelligence! Nothing has caused the  human race more trouble. Modern  marriage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff swings his chair back to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've progressed emotionally in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting) Baloney! Once it was see somebody,  get excited, get married -- Now,  it's read books, fence with four  syllable words, psychoanalyze each  other until you can't tell a petting  party from a civil service exam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People have different emotional levels  that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting again) Ask for trouble and you get it. Why  there's a good boy in my neighborhood  who went with a nice girl across the  street for three years. Then he  refused to marry her. Why? -- Because  she only scored sixty-one on a Look  Magazine marriage quiz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff can't help smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I married Myles, we were both  maladjusted misfits. We still are.  And we've loved every minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, Stella. Now would you  make me a sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- but I'm going to spread some  common sense on the bread. Lisa  Fremont's loaded to her fingertips  with love for you. I'll give you two  words of advice. Marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles) She pay you much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stella leaves for the kitchen in a huff. Jeff turns his c to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff now looks out to see what has happened to the old la and the man with the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elderly lady is now asleep in her deck chair, her fac covered with the Herald Tribune. There is no sign of the with the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's eyes travel up to the ballet dancer's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is sitting near the window looking into an upright mi Dreamily, and methodically, she is brushing her long copp colored hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are suddenly turned in another direction, sharpl to his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is now looking at the windows of the apartments neares to him. A shade has gone up, and a man, obviously a caret is raising a window with some effort. Having accomplished this, he turns back into the room, and we now see him app a young man and woman who are standing just inside the  doorway. He hands a key to the young man, and then obligi brings in two suitcases which he places on the floor besi them. He gives them a studied, but agreeable nod, then  departs. We now see that the girl has a small hat with a veil, and ornate corsage pinned to her light blue tailored suit. Th boy, who like the girl is perhaps twenty years old, wears dark blue serge suit and a grey felt hat. He takes off th hat, and scales it over to a nearby chair. Quickly they a in each other's arms, kissing passionately, crushing the  girl's corsage and pushing her hat back a little. They pa the boy laughs nervously, and takes a furtive glance out  toward the corridor. He looks back into the room, and bec her to come out. She follows him wonderingly. For a momen both are lost from sight. When they reappear, he is carry her in his arms, over the threshold. He sets her down, cl the door, and they kiss again. They part, still holding hands and looking into each othe eyes. Then slowly, and significantly, she looks toward th open window. He releases her hands, goes to the window an pull down the shade, as she is reaching upward with both  hands to unpin her hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a soft, understanding look on Jeff's face, and h gives an involuntary sigh. He is unaware that Stella is n standing behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) Window shopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He freezes, turns slowly to look up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA makes a short sweep around the neighborhood sh that some of the rooms are now with their lights on. The CAMERA PULLS BACK into Jeff's apartment until his hea fills the screen. He is asleep. A shadow of some other pe creeps over his face. His eyes start to open. He looks up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen is filled with the eyes, nose and mouth of a w coming nearer and nearer to the CAMERA to kiss Jeff. The  face is more or less in shadow, a faint light coming onto the profile from the window. It moves down until the lips move out of her bottom of her screen, and just the remain for fill the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two big profiles filling the screen. The girl kisses  Jeff firmly, but not passionately. Then her head moves ba an inch or two. She speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Softly) How's your leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm -- hurts a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your stomach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty as a football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you love life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too active.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else bothering you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives a low. Warm laugh, and the CAMERA PULLS BACK to show that Lisa has been bending over Jeff's wheelchair fr the side. As she straightens up, it PANS her swiftly over the corner of the room, keeping her in big closeup. She t on a low, hanging light. We see her full facial beauty for the first time. It is a warm, intelligent face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As she moves) Reading from top to bottom -- (Light on) Lisa --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA FOLLOWS HER quickly to another lamp. She gets little farther away from us so that we now see her down t her waist. She turns on the second lamp and the light sho us that her beauty is not alone in her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS HER over to a third lamp which she turns She is now full figure, beautifully groomed and flawless. Her dress is high-style fashion and dramatic evening wear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fremont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff looks across the room at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lisa Fremont who never wears the  same dress twice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only because it's expected of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does a professional model's turn in the dress showing off its features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right off the Paris plane. Think it  will sell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff replies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on the quote. Let's see --  there's the plane tickets over, import  duties, hidden taxes, profit markups --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- A steal at eleven hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A low whistle) That dress should be listed on the  stock exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sell a dozen a day in this price  range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who buys them? Tax collectors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if I had to pay, it would be   worth it -- just for the occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down at the long mahogany table beside her whic is littered with a number of his personal effects. Her own handbag is also on the table. As she talks her ey scan the table as if she's looking for something specific

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Off -- puzzled) Something big going on somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking up from the  table) Going on right here. It's a big night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Off) It's just a run-of-the-mill Monday.  The calendar's loaded with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa finds what she has been looking for. Picks up an old and cracked cigarette box, examines it as she talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's opening night of the last  depressing week of L. B. Jefferies  in a cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Off) Hasn't been any big demand for  tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to look at him, and moves toward him, carrying cigarette box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiling) That's because I bought out the house.  This cigarette box has seen better  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa facing Jeff in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picked it up in Shanghai -- which  has also seen better days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cracked -- and you never use  it. And it's too ornate. I'm sending  up a plain, flat silver one -- with  just your initials engraved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's no way to spend your hard-  earned money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to, Jeff. (A sudden intake of  breath) Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns around quickly and dashes to the door, dropping the cigarette box on the table as she passes, THE CAMERA  PANNING with her. She goes up the two steps, stops, turns back to Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you think of starting off  with dinner at the "21"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have, perhaps, an ambulance  outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches for the doorknob, turns it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Simply) Better than that. The "21."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She swings open the door and stands to one side. Framed i the doorway is middle-aged waiter wearing a white linen p jacket with a red collar. He's carrying in one hand a lar portable warming oven, and in the other hand an ice bucke containing a bottle of wine covered with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His reaction is one of tender amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for waiting Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles, nods enters. He goes down the stairs, as she  follows. THE CAMERA GOES with both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitchen's on the left. I'll take the  wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her the wine bucket and she places it on the tab He moves toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr Jefferies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Up, to Carl) Just put everything right in the  oven Carl. On "low."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Off) Yes ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Enthusiastically) Let's open the wine now. It's a  Montrachet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Appreciatively) A big glassful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves to a small bar set in the wall cabinet. Produces two glasses, hold them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Corkscrew's on the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds it. Puts the glasses on the table, uncovers the wine, and begins screwing in the corkscrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't think of anything more  boring and tiresome than what you've  been through. And the last week must  be the hardest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I want to get this thing off  and get moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Struggling with cork) Well, I'm going to make this a week  you'll never forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl comes out of the kitchen carrying the empty warming  oven. He sets it down he sees Lisa struggling with the  corkscrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does. He takes out his own professional corkscrew, qu inserts it and levers the cork out. He deftly wraps the n around the bottle and pours the wine, replacing the bottl in the wine bucket. Lisa has opened her purse to produce  some money, in bills. She hands it to the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will take care of the taxi as  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, without looking at the money, puts it in his pocket

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Fremont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the warning oven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a pleasant dinner, Mr. Jefferies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl goes up the stairs and out the door, while THE CAMER REMAINS on Lisa and Jeff. She picks up both glasses of wi and walks toward Jeff. She seats herself on the windowsil as she hands him his glass. We notice that the outside is considerably darker by now, and the lights are beginning come on in the various apartments outside. They raise the glasses in a silent toast, and sip the wine. THE CAMERA C IN until they are both in a tight TOW SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a day I've had!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a bit. I was all morning in a  sales meeting. Then over to the  Waldorf for a quick drink with Madame  Dufresne -- just over from Paris.  With some spy reports. Back to the  "21" for lunch with the Harper's  Bazaar people -- that's when I ordered  dinner. Then two Fall showings --  twenty blocks apart. Then I had to  have a cocktail with Leland and Slim  Hayward -- we're trying to get his  next show. (Softly, looking up  to him) Then I had to dash back and change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mock seriousness --  one girl to another) Tell me -- what was Slim Hayward  wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Seriously) She looked very cool. She had on a  mint green --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks off with a little laugh, and a slight reproach look at Jeff. She sips her drink then says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to think, I planted three nice  items about you in the columns today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's opinion of that is a short chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't buy that kind of publicity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday you might want to open up  your own studio here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I run it from say --  Pakistan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts down her glass and slides along the window seat  nearer to him, THE CAMERA CLOSING IN. She looks up at him with a serious frankness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff -- isn't it time you came home?  You could pick your assignment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish there was one I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make the one you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As if he can't believe  her) You mean leave the magazine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For yourself -- and me. (She adds eagerly) I could get you a dozen assignments  tomorrow... fashion, portraits --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff interrupts her with soft laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Offended) Don't laugh. -- I could do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm afraid of. (He gazes into space) Could you see me -- driving down to  the fashion salon in a jeep -- wearing  combat boots and a three day beard? (He chuckles at the  thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could see you looking handsome and  successful in a dark blue flannel  suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking directly at  her) Let's not talk any more nonsense,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands up. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better start setting up for  dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves away behind him, into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JEFF'S APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jeff gives a sigh of relief, exhaling his breath, then lo down toward his legs in thought. He holds this attitude f just a moment, then seems to shake off his concern to lif his head and turn his attention to what might be happenin in his neighborhood beyond his window. Behind him we see the vague form of Lisa bringing in a ca table, which she proceeds to unfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's attention is concentrated on an apartment we have seen before. This belongs to a single woman, about forty  years of age. She lives alone. Her apartment is below tha of the salesman with the invalid wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff leans forward with increased interest. Behind him we get vague figure of Lisa laying a cloth over the card tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nearer view show us a more intimate picture of the woma Jeff is concentrating on. She is thin and unattractive. A the moment, she is putting on her make-up in front of the bedroom mirror. She gives a half turn and picks up a pair horn-rimmed glasses, which she puts on, and leans nearer her mirror. She picks up a lipstick and proceeds to paint her lips carefully. Having completed her make-up, she takes off her glasses a surveys her face in the mirror. She stands up, swings the skirt of her dress around, admires herself in the mirror. She is quite flat-chested, and the dress hangs unattracti She lifts her chin, gives one last look, and turns toward her living room. As if she's preparing to meet someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without taking his eyes from the scene, Jeff picks up his wineglass and drinks. As he drinks, his eyes move slightl over.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEIGHBORHOOD NIGHT
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA HAS PANNED slightly to the woman's living room window. A small, candle-lit table is set up, with dinner two. The spinster sweeps into the room, smiling. She goes the door, opens it, and in pantomime admits an imaginary  caller. She pretends to kiss him lightly, take his hat, a place the hat on a chair. Then she shows him to a seat at the table, disappears into an unseen kitchen and returns  with a bottle and two glasses. She sits down, pours two  drinks. She lifts her drink in a toast to the imaginary m opposite her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff gives a faint, sympathetic smile, and subconsciously raises his glass in response. In the background, Lisa, ha just placed a pair of candlesticks on the table, is retur to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having finished her drink, the lonesome woman pours herse another one. Then she starts to take a sip, smiling acros the table at her imaginary guest. She lowers the glass on the table. The smile fades from her face as her head drop Suddenly she buries her head in her arms over the table a starts to sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff, his glass in hand, looks out sympathetically. He is unaware that Lisa is standing behind him, and is also wat this little drama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what is know as "manless  melancholia."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nods agreement) Miss Lonely Hearts. At least that's  something you'll never have to worry  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? You can see my apartment all the  way up on 63rd street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly -- but we have a little  apartment here that's probably about  as popular as yours. (He points) You, of course, remember Miss Torso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of them swing their eyes a little to the left.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEIGHBORHOOD NIGHT
dialogues.text: The kitchen-lining room combination of the ballet dancer' apartment has now been made more presentable. The ice box is now skillfully concealed by a large Chines screen. All kitchen utensils have been put away, replaced more attractive effects, and lamp light softens the  surroundings. Miss Torso is now wearing a cocktail dress, which shows o her figure to great advantage, especially when she leans  toward three assorted men to offer them a plate of hors d oeuvres. She is the perfect hostess, animated, charming, with an added personal touch for each guest. She is behav with a sophistication which was not apparent when we firs saw her in the morning. Her every movement is followed  admiringly by the eyes of the three men -- one wearing bl tie, with a touch of grey in his hair, a Long Island soci a young rather handsome, actor in grey flannel suit -- an last, a bright, pleasant, young man who might possibly be from Wall street, wearing a blue-pin-striped suit. The la two are engaged in an animated conversation. The young ma in the grey suit is showing the other young man some news cuttings he's taken from his pocket. Miss Torso sees that the cocktail glass of the third man empty. She takes it over to the window, and starts to fil it. The man in the tuxedo follows her over, with a casual glance toward the other two. He stands beside her as she  makes the drink. He looks at his watch with some impatien and makes a side comment to her as to the lateness of the time. She turns, gives him a light kiss on his cheek, as she's telling him to be patient. Instead of pacifying him it makes him more amorous, and he puts an arm around her  shoulder an plants a heavy kiss on her cheek. She turns t face him, they look into each other's eyes a moment, and allows herself to be kissed on the lips -- but only long  enough so as to attract the attention of the other two me With a little admonishing look, she moves away from him, makes him rejoin the other two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff turns and looks up to Lisa with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she picked the most prosperous  looking one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not in love with him -- or any  of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell that -- from here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it resembled my apartment,  didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves away with a significant look to him. THE CAMERA MOVES IN until Jeff is in semi-closeup, alone. He ponders over her last remark, then changes his look to another direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The newlyweds's apartment has the shades still drawn. Although there's a light burning inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a slight, but warm, smile on Jeff's face as he l at the drawn shade. His eyes move away from the newlyweds apartment, and slowly explore the neighborhood to his rig He finds something of interest, and stops to stare at it. His face sobers at what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The salesman's apartment. We see both the living room and the bedroom. The salesman has prepared a dinner tray, and carrying it from the kitchen, through the lining room, in the bedroom. He places it on the lap of his wife, sitting in bed. He puts a couple of pillows behind her back to ma her more comfortable. She doesn't bother to thank him, but is busy examining th content of the tray. Her attitude shows her dissatisfacti Nothing is right. It's not what she wanted, and it's badl prepared. She begins criticizing him. He starts to answer her back, but decides better of it, and instead, leaves t room. He goes to the kitchen reaches up to a wall cabinet takes down a bottle and pours himself a drink. Then he re to the lining room, listens a moment. The wife is grudgin beginning to eat the dinner. The husband quietly lifts a  phone from the cradle, and dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff becomes completely absorbed with he sees. He leans  forward a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get a better view of the salesman waiting while his  connection is being made. Whoever he has called answers. instantly there is a marked change in his attitude. He  relaxes, smiles, is warm. He talks softly, perhaps guarde with an occasional glance at the bedroom door. In the bed his wife has become aware of the call. Quietly she moves the tray, gets out of bed, and goes to bedroom door to listen. The wall hides her from our view. Then suddenly, she apparently opens the door, because the living room, we see her arm suddenly appear, pointing at man and the telephone. He speaks quickly into the phone, hangs up. His face is flushed and angry as he goes toward the bedroom. In the bedroom his wife appears walking back the bed, followed by the husband. She is laughing, and he answering her in angry tones. She climbs in bed laughing. The more she laughs, the more angry he gets, and the hard she laughs. Finally, he leaves the room, goes into the li room, back into the kitchen and has another drink. He sta there, controlling an outburst of emotion, and seems almo to be crushing the shot glass in his clenched fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Jeff has been engaged in watching this little drama the SOUND of a piano has started. He now diverts his atte from the salesman's apartment to the source of the piano  music. He turns his eyes in the direction of the composer apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the studio window of the song-writer's apartment see the man at work again on his original melody, and he farther along the line of the melody than before. It is beginning to take some shape, and give promise of i full beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff, listening to the composer. His head turns as Lisa's voice comes over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Emerging from kitchen) Where's that music coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA QUICKLY PULL BACK as Jeff swings his chair aro Lisa is emerging from the kitchen, carrying the serving d of their lobster thermidor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... some songwriter. In the studio  apartment. Lives alone. Probably had  an unhappy marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Putting down the  food) I think it's enchanting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls up a chair and seats herself at the card table. now observe that two small lit candles adorn the table, a the rest of the room lights are out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost as if it were being written  especially for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pleasantly) No wonder he's having so much trouble  with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faint shade of disappointment is seen on Lisa's face; b she quickly recovers and looks down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least you can't say the  dinner isn't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff looks at her soberly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, it's perfect (Looks down at the  food, without  enthusiasm) As always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brightness drains from Lisa's face, and she lowers he eyes slowly toward the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa slowly helping Jeff to lobster from the main dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting over Jeff's shoulder we see beyond him the divan bed upon which Lisa is stretched out. There is one light  burning, behind Lisa's head. A fierce discussion is in  progress. Lisa gesticulates with her hands, body and legs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There can't be that much difference  between people and the way they live!  We all eat, talk, drink, laugh, sleep,  wear clothes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff raises both his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa draws back one leg, and points a finger challengingl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're saying all this just because  you don't want to tell me the truth,  because you're hiding something from  me, then maybe I can understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing I'm hiding. It's  just that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Won't let him break  in) It doesn't make sense to me. What's  so different about it here from over  there, or any place you go, that one  person couldn't live in both places  just as easily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people can. Now if you'll let  me explain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Ignores him) What is it but traveling from one  place to another, taking pictures?  It's just like being a tourist on an  endless vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. That's your opinion. You're  entitled to it, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ridiculous for you to say that  it can only be done by a special,  private little group of anointed  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff begin to get desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a simple, but true statement  and I'll back it up, if you'll just  shut up for a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, stretched out on the divan. She looks at him for a  moment without speaking. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your opinion is as rude as your  manner, I'm not sure I want to hear  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Jeff's hand coming to the foreground with a restra gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Soothing her) Lisa, simmer down -- will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Something starts her  up again) You can't fit in here -- I can't fit  in there. According to you, people  should be born, live an die on the  same --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Loud, sharp) Lisa! Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa turns on her side, and stares into the room, angrily

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment of silence, Jeff says earnestly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever eat fish heads and rice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might have to, if you went with  me. Ever try to keep warm in a C-54,  at fifteen thousand feet, at twenty  below zero?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, still looking out into the room, and without turnin says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I do that all the time. Whenever  I have a few minutes after lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever get shot at, run over, sandbagged  at night because people got  unfavorable publicity from your  camera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer, obviously annoyed at the unnecessary  questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those high heels would be a lot of  use in the jungle -- and those nylons  and six-ounce lingerie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quickly) Three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they'd be very stylish in  Finland -- just before you froze to  death. Begin to get the idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns at last, and looks across at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's one thing I know, it's  how to wear the proper clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING OVER LISA'S SHOULDER, and down her body, with Je in the chair beyond. Jeff says, as if remembering some ol experience:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Try and find a raincoat in  Brazil. Even when it isn't raining (Squints at her) Lisa, on this job you carry one  suitcase. Your home is the available  transportation. You sleep rarely,  bathe even less, and sometime the  food you even look at when they were  alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff, you don't have to be  deliberately repulsive just to impress  me I'm wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anything, I'm making it sound  good. (A thoughtful pause) Let's face it, Lisa... you aren't  made for that kind of a life. Few  people are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa realizes she is getting nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too stubborn to argue with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff, getting angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not stubborn! I'm truthful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, with sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. A lesser man would have told  me it was one long holiday -- and I  would have awakened to a rude  disillusionment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is definitely angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now if you want to get vicious, I'd  be very happy to accommodate you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa starts to rise from the divan, THE CAMERA PANNING UP She moves away from THE CAMERA into the center of the roo as she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Wearily) No. I don't particularly want that. (She turns, faces him) So that's it. You won't stay here --  I can't go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff looks across at her with some concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be the wrong thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, from Jeff's viewpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think either one of us  could ever change?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, it doesn't seem so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa begins to move around the room assembling her posses preparatory to leaving. She puts a comb, and other effect into a handbag. She gets her stole. All this as she talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Simply) I'm in love with you. I don't care  what you do for a living. Somehow I  would just like to be part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff starts to say something then thinks better of it, an remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa pauses in the act of gathering her things together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's deflating to find out that  the only way I can be part of it --  is to take out a subscription to  your magazine. I guess I'm not the  girl I thought I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with you, Lisa.  You have the town in the palm of  your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks at Jeff) Not quite -- it seems. (Tosses a stole over  her shoulder) Goodbye, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean "goodnight."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's eyes follow her up the steps toward the door. He c out to her, impulsively, as we HEAR the SOUND of the door opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa turns in the half-opened door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we just sort of keep things  status quo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without any future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff tries to be pleasant, and offhand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- when'll I see you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, standing in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for a long time. Not, at least  until -- (She begins smiling) -- tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continues smiling as she close the door softly behind her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pleasantness on Jeff's face slowly melts into baffled discouragement. He reaches for a nearby phone picks up th receiver, dials. It buzzes on filter. Receiver up on filter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Filter) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunnison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Is that you, Jeff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word is "everything." Now what  time does my plane leave Tuesday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Unhappy) Jeff --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Won't give him time  to argue) I don't care where it goes -- just  as long as I'm on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Wearily, after pause) Okay. Indo-China. Tuesday. We'll  pick you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's more like it. Goodnight, old  buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff hangs up, looks up to the door through which Lisa le He's not particularly happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff returns to the window. He lights a cigarette and smo it peacefully, as he contemplates the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA slowly sweeps over the various apartments with odd window lit here and there. In the distant street ther is still some traffic passing, with one or two pedestrian going by. THE CAMERA completes its sweep, and starts to m back again. Somewhere a dog howls. The PANNING CAMERA com to a sudden halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff smiles a little, but as the howl continues, his  expressions sobers. His eyes begin to scan the neighborho as if looking for the source. He fails to find it, and si there, puzzled and disturbed. The scene, and the sound of the dog:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's chair is turned facing the window so that we see t darkened room behind him. There is just one side light  burning, which illuminates the side of his face. His head nods sleepily as he dozes. He opens his eyes and looks out, as a slight sound of rain starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his viewpoint we see the first few drops of rain sta to fall. It is sort, gentle rain, not a downpour. There a still some windows lit in the neighborhood. The apartment house corridors all have small night lights burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff wakens a little more fully as his attentions is draw to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The couple who sleep on the fire escape. The increasing r cause them to hastily gather their things to retreat insi The man, hurriedly untying the alarm clock from the raili of the fire escape, lets it slip through his fingers. As falls to the garden below, the CAMERA FANS SWIFTLY down w it. When the clock hits the ground, the alarm goes off se a shrill sound through the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff smiles at the incident, and then lowers his eyes sli as something else catches his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming out of his apartment into the corridor on the floo below is the salesman with the nagging wife. The shades a drawn in his apartment, but a light burns dimly behind th The salesman carries a large aluminum suitcase -- the sam one we saw him with earlier in the day. The sound of the  alarm startles him. He turns toward the window a moment  listening. Then reassured that is is nothing important, h turns and moves down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is puzzled. He looks down a moment in thought. Then darts his eyes and swings them toward the left. He looks steadily toward the distant street corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street corner, lighted by a lamp, is deserted. A mome later, the salesman, still carrying the suitcase, moves  diagonally across the corner, head down against the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff looks wonderingly at this nocturnal activity. Then h looks down at his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's watch reads 1:55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The watch now reads 2:35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More puzzled, allows his eyes to travel from the street t the apartment corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The salesman is see coming down the corridor to his apart still carrying the aluminum case. He quickly enters his  apartment door in a business-like manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff starts to assume a thoughtful air, when he is startl by a light which falls across his face from the right. He looks toward the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light comes from the song-writer's apartment. His doo is open, and he is hanging onto the door frame, his hand  still on the light switch. He surveys his apartment. He  appears rather drunk. He comes into the apartment, closes the door behind him, and sways a little. He wears a hat,  pushed back on his forehead, and no raincoat. His clothes are quite wet. He might have even fallen. He looks disgustedly at the piano, then lurches toward it There is no doubt now as the state of his drunkenness. At the piano he viciously sweeps all the note paper off the  music stand. This seems to give him some satisfaction, bu he loses his balance, twists sideways, and fall into a ne chair. He remains there, bleary-eyed and a little sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he has observed seems to give Jeff an idea. He moves his wheelchair backward and to the left alongside the sid board. Awkwardly, with his left hand, he reaches up for a bottle of whiskey. He cradles the bottle in his lap, and  reaches for a tumbler. He then wheels back to the window, and pours himself a good, long drink. He lifts up the gla starts to drink, but something happening beyond his windo startles him and he stops in the middle of his drink, his eyes a little wider then usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The salesman is again leaving his apartment with his alum suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's eyes travel down to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief moment or two. Then the salesman, carrying his  aluminum case, crosses the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's face is expressionless. He just stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's head is nodding and dozing again. The side light f the song-writer's apartment is no longer on his face. Jef eyes open, then his head comes up quickly, trying to clea the sleep from his mind, as he remembers the object of hi vigilance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The salesman's apartment shows the shades drawn and a dim light burning behind them. The CAMERA PANS to the empty  corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's eyes turn sharply in the direction of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is deserted. At the right hand side of the scr a light goes on. THE CAMERA PANS OVER and we see that Mis Torso has returned from her date. She is wearing a three- quarter length coat over her evening dress. She is inside with the door two-thirds closed, but she leans out to kis someone goodnight. Then it takes some coaxing to get the  door completely closed. She turns the key in the lock. She listens a moment then  comes to the center of the room. She takes her coat off a drapes it over chair. She removes the screen in front of ice box, then opens the ice box. She searches it for something to eat; finds a big piece o pumpkin pie. She closes the ice box. She starts to eat th pie as she moves in the direction of the bathroom. Stoppi a moment, she puts the piece of pie on a table, and proce to take off her dress. Undoing the zippers, she slides it over her head as she passes into the bathroom. The dress thrown on a nearby chair, and the bare arm picks up a pie of pie. She is now in the bathroom. We see her slip down brassiere straps, but the window does not permit us to se any lower. As she munches on the pie, she pulls out a few pins holding up her hair, which she proceeds to brush  rhythmically. She turns and moves down her bare back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
